title: China donates 20 million BIF of humanitarian aid to the Bujumbura Public Orphanage in December 2020
description: On December 16, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Burundi donated supplies, worth 20 million Burundian francs, to the Bujumbura Public Orphanage in Burundi. The supplies included 5 boxes of Nido, 100 bags of rice, 100 bags of corn flour noodles, 100 buckets of cooking oil, 4,000,000 kilograms of briquette, 50 cartons of milk, 30 cans of milk powder, stationery, and other school supplies. The Chinese Embassy also repaired the roof on one room of the orphanage and has further plans to repair the other three roofs in the next six months.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China donates 20 million BIF of humanitarian aid to the Bujumbura Public Orphanage in December 2020

# Description
On December 16, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Burundi donated supplies, worth 20 million Burundian francs, to the Bujumbura Public Orphanage in Burundi. The supplies included 5 boxes of Nido, 100 bags of rice, 100 bags of corn flour noodles, 100 buckets of cooking oil, 4,000,000 kilograms of briquette, 50 cartons of milk, 30 cans of milk powder, stationery, and other school supplies. The Chinese Embassy also repaired the roof on one room of the orphanage and has further plans to repair the other three roofs in the next six months.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and social welfare without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of food supplies, school materials, and orphanage repairs with no energy-related components

title: China donates 7th batch of anti-epidemic materials worth USD 550,000 to Burundi for the fight against Covid-19 in November 2020
description: On November 3, 2020, China donated its 7th batch of anti-epidemic materials, worth USD 550,000, to Burundi. The materials donated included 50 respirators, 50 oxygen concentrators, 200 respirator accessories, 160,000 N95 masks, 50,000 surgical masks, 500 infrared thermometers, and other medical equipment. The handover ceremony took place in Burundi's Basic Medicine Procurement Center..
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates 7th batch of anti-epidemic materials worth USD 550,000 to Burundi for the fight against Covid-19 in November 2020

# Description
On November 3, 2020, China donated its 7th batch of anti-epidemic materials, worth USD 550,000, to Burundi. The materials donated included 50 respirators, 50 oxygen concentrators, 200 respirator accessories, 160,000 N95 masks, 50,000 surgical masks, 500 infrared thermometers, and other medical equipment. The handover ceremony took place in Burundi's Basic Medicine Procurement Center..
justification: Project is focused on healthcare support with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medical equipment for COVID-19 response, including respirators, masks, and thermometers

title: China donates 2nd batch of anti-epidemic materials to the Confucius Institute at the University of Burundi for the fight against Covid-19 in December 2020 (Linked to ID#92110)
description: On December 3, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Burundi donated the 2nd batch of anti-epidemic materials to the Confucius Institute at the University of Burundi. The "epidemic prevention health kits" were given to the teachers and volunteers at the Institute..  This project is linked to Project ID#92110, which captures the first batch of anti-epidemic materials donated to the Confucius Institute at the University of Burundi.

title: Chinese Embassy in Burundi donates audiovisual equipment worth BIF 80 million to Burundi National Radio and Television Station in August 2020
description: On August 20, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Burundi donated a batch of audiovisual equipment, worth BIF 80 million, to the Burundi National Radio and Television Station. The donated items included 2 professional video cameras, 20 laptops, and other materials. These new materials will help TV reporters in Burundi improve their work level and abilities.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Burundi donates audiovisual equipment worth BIF 80 million to Burundi National Radio and Television Station in August 2020

# Description
On August 20, 2020, the Chinese Embassy in Burundi donated a batch of audiovisual equipment, worth BIF 80 million, to the Burundi National Radio and Television Station. The donated items included 2 professional video cameras, 20 laptops, and other materials. These new materials will help TV reporters in Burundi improve their work level and abilities.
justification: Project involves donation of audiovisual equipment to improve media capabilities, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of audiovisual equipment to national radio and television station, focus on improving media capabilities

title: China donates 300 desks and chairs to Mushasa Primary School in Burundi in response to area flooding in August 2020
description: On August 21, 2020, the Chinese Embassy jointly organized the donation of 300 sets of desks and chairs to the Mushasa Primary School in Gatumba County, Bujumbura Rural Province. The donation was jointly organized by the Chinese Embassy in Burundi, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and Burundi's Ministry of National Education and Research. The Chinese side is responsible for the production of desks and chairs, the United Nations agencies were responsible for material transportation, organization and coordination, and the Burundi side is responsible for material distribution. This donation was made in response to the severe flooding that impacted the area.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
China donates 300 desks and chairs to Mushasa Primary School in Burundi in response to area flooding in August 2020

# Description
On August 21, 2020, the Chinese Embassy jointly organized the donation of 300 sets of desks and chairs to the Mushasa Primary School in Gatumba County, Bujumbura Rural Province. The donation was jointly organized by the Chinese Embassy in Burundi, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and Burundi's Ministry of National Education and Research. The Chinese side is responsible for the production of desks and chairs, the United Nations agencies were responsible for material transportation, organization and coordination, and the Burundi side is responsible for material distribution. This donation was made in response to the severe flooding that impacted the area.
justification: Project is focused on educational infrastructure support following natural disaster, with no direct energy or environmental implications
evidence: Donation of desks and chairs to primary school, humanitarian response to flooding

title: China donates AIDS medicine and medical equipment worth USD 400,000 to Burundi in April 2020
description: On April 4, 2020, China donated AIDS medicines and medical equipment, worth USD 400,000, to the Burundi Ministry of Public Health. The materials are meant to help the country's fight against AIDS. The donated materials will be used in the resuscitation and surgery departments at the Prince Regent Charles Hospital.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title

# Description
On April 4, 2020, China donated AIDS medicines and medical equipment, worth USD 400,000, to the Burundi Ministry of Public Health. The materials are meant to help the country's fight against AIDS. The donated materials will be used in the resuscitation and surgery departments at the Prince Regent Charles Hospital.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare support without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Donation of AIDS medicines and medical equipment for hospital use

title: China's Qinghai Province donates anti-epidemic supplies to Burundi for the fight against Covid-19 in May 2020
description: On May 28, 2020, China's Qinghai Province donated anti-epidemic supplies to Burundi. The supplies included 1,000 sets of disposable medical protective clothing, 30,240 medical surgical masks, 3,000 medical protective masks, 300 goggles, and 20 infrared induction thermometers from Qinghai Provincial Health and Health Commission.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector

On May 28, 2020, China's Qinghai Province donated anti-epidemic supplies to Burundi. The supplies included 1,000 sets of disposable medical protective clothing, 30,240 medical surgical masks, 3,000 medical protective masks, 300 goggles, and 20 infrared induction thermometers from Qinghai Provincial Health and Health Commission.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for public health purposes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-epidemic supplies including protective equipment and medical devices for COVID-19 response

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Burundi in 2020
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Burundi signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020).   Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount is unknown but was likely no more than $384,000 (the total estimated suspension amount in 2021). At the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’   The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Burundi. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0.2. The total estimated suspension amount in 2021 is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Burundi secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Burundi in 2020

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China Eximbank and the Government of Burundi signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020).   Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2020 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount is unknown but was likely no more than $384,000 (the total estimated suspension amount in 2021). At the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’   The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt service suspension agreement is a financial arrangement with no direct environmental impact
evidence: Debt suspension agreement, focus on financial terms and COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Embassy funds multi-functional stadium in Burundi
description: On February 2, 2020, the Chinese Ambassador to Burundi Li Changlin attended the handover ceremony of the multi-functional stadium of the Ministry of Public Security and Disaster Management. Melchiade RUCEKE, director of the Ministry of Public Security in Burundi, and Wang Yuan, political counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Burundi, attended the ceremony. The stadium was funded by the Chinese Embassy in Burundi and undertaken by China Geological Engineering Corporation.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
Chinese Embassy funds multi-functional stadium in Burundi

# Description
On February 2, 2020, the Chinese Ambassador to Burundi Li Changlin attended the handover ceremony of the multi-functional stadium of the Ministry of Public Security and Disaster Management. Melchiade RUCEKE, director of the Ministry of Public Security in Burundi, and Wang Yuan, political counselor of the Chinese Embassy in Burundi, attended the ceremony. The stadium was funded by the Chinese Embassy in Burundi and undertaken by China Geological Engineering Corporation.
justification: Project is a multi-functional stadium with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Stadium construction, no energy or environmental components mentioned
